Chicago, Illinois

Population: 2,833,321

Metro Area Population: 9,505,748

Chicago has the third largest gross metropolitan product in the nation (approximately $440 billion) based on 2007 estimates. It also has recorded the greatest number of new or expanded corporate facilities in the U.S. for six of the past seven years.

Trends of Employment

Chicago is a major financial center with the second largest central business district in the U.S. The city has been rated as having the most balanced economy in the U.S., due to its high level of of diversification. Manufacturing, printing, and food processing play major roles in the city's economy. Chicago is a major transportation and distribution center. It is also a major convention destination.

Cost of Living

Chichago's cost of living in 26.45% higher than the U.S. average. The Chicago-Naperville-Joilet Metro Area's cost of living is 12.64% higher than the U.S. Average.

Based on Sperling's Best Places, Chicago's income per capita is $23,303, which includes all adults and children. The median household income is $44,664. In the greater metro area, the income per capita is $28,399 and the median household income is $58,445.

Transportation

The average one-way commute in Chicago, IL, takes 39 minutes. The CTA rail line (the "L") offers public transportation in the area. Chicago hosts three international airports: O'Hare International Airport (ORD), Midway International Airport (MDW), and Gary-Chicago International Airport (GYY).
